awd_titl_txt: ICN-WEN: Collaborative Research: ICN-Enabled Secure Edge Networking with Augmented Reality
awd_abstract_narration:
Technological advances have moved society into an exciting era of mobile computing.  Our daily lives can be further enriched by a new generation of mobile applications, such as augmented reality (AR) which broadens one's real-world perception by harmonizing sound, image, video, and sensors from multiple sources to aid comprehension and navigation.  However, today's Internet operates with the address-based TCP/IP protocol architecture developed 40 years ago, which greatly limits the full promises of these new applications. Thus, current AR implementations face challenges in performance, scalability and  availability upon disasters.  This proposed research project (ICE-AR) aims to develop a new wireless network architecture to address these limitations and provide pervasive support for these emerging applications.

The ICE-AR project team will apply and extend six years of research efforts on Named Data Networking (NDN), a realization of the Information Centric Networking (ICN) vision, to create this new architecture.  The design emphasizes application-level data naming, data-centric security and computing, asynchronous publishing and consumption, and efficient use of local and proximate resources. The architecture will unify latest advances in wireless communication with domain-specific computing technologies to accelerate AR at the wireless edge and deliver robust performance, with or without the pre-deployed infrastructure support.

ICN-Enabled Secure Edge Networking with Augmented Reality (ICE-AR) Outcome Report

The “ICN-Enabled Secure Edge Networking with Augmented Reality (ICE-AR)” project successfully finished its 5-year mission, from 2017 to 2022, of developing data-centric building blocks to enable a new era of interconnecting users, applications, and smart devices, big and small, in a securely and seamlessly way via fetching named, secured data. Using application names for network layer data fetching brings fundamental advantages: it can enable discovery of local resources through network routing and forwarding, removing the dependency on the cloud or special lookup services; and it can make networking, computation, and storage all become equally viable sources for requested data. Furthermore, naming data enables intrinsic, end-to-end security protection directly on data itself without dependency on the security of underlying communication paths, and enables treating cryptographic keys and trust policies all as semantically named data, making them resiliently available, and facilitating the automation of security executions.

This project validated a key premise of the Named Data Networking (NDN) architecture, a specific realization of Information Centric Networking (ICN), i.e., NDN can indeed enable interactive AR applications at the wireless edge through systematic naming and retrieving named, secured data at the system’s thin waist. Using application names at the network layer enables direct discovery of local resources through network routing and forwarding. Such a design removes dependency on either the cloud or other look-up services. More importantly, networking, computation, and storage can all become equally viable sources for the requested data. Each resource, regardless of the type, can simply announce its availability via its name (prefix), and NDN’s intelligent forwarding can select the best option for the given task. Overall, we have been able to follow the basic NDN design tenets, including application-driven data naming, data-centric security, and asynchronous content production and consumption, in the new scenario of wireless edge computing. We started ICE-AR with experimentations of Augmented Reality applications over NDN; at the end, we applied what we learned from ICE-AR to explore the design space of metaverse applications over NDN. 

While this project further strengthens our confidence that semantically named, secured data offers the right basic building block for networking new generations of applications, during the project we also identified new challenges in applying data-centric networking to the existent application technologies and platforms that have been designed and optimized for the incumbent TCP/IP networking, such as the lack of access to low-level protocol layers in major OS platforms, and omission of basic security supporting primitives, or easy access to plug security into, in the existing application packages; similar challenges exist in modifying media CODECs for granular and random-access delivery. We learned an important lesson from our attempt of introducing NDN into contemporary applications and platforms, a lesson that makes a unique contribution to network architecture research in general: the impact of a new network architecture, once successful, goes far beyond the network layer itself. IP’s unicast delivery influenced both the link layer design choices as well as applications’ view of networking. These influences in turn become formidable barriers to the change of network layer delivery model.  We also gained full appreciation of the challenges and importance of integrating hardware accelerators, such as those implemented in the field-programmable gate-arrays (FPGAs), into the software stack, and the need for rapid synthesis of hardware accelerators from application-level specifications as opposed to manual RTL coding for support various AR applications. 

The outcome of this project can be found on the following websites, which will be maintained by the NDN research team beyond the ICE-AR project duration:

  • the ICE-AR Project website: http://ice-ar.named-data.net/;
  • the NDN codebase (a repository for all NDN-related code development, including the ICE-AR produced code): https://named-data.net/codebase/platform/; and
  • the NDN publication page: https://named-data.net/publications/ . 

The ICE-AR project contributed to the global movement toward Information-Centric Networking to further evolve the Internet architecture. ICE-AR contributed multiple papers to ACM Information Centric Networking conference (ACM-ICN) each year, and contributed to the special sessions devoted to NDN-related research outcome at IEEE MILCOM 2018 and 2021. The ICE-AR outcomes have also been reported at annual NDN Community Meetings hosted by NIST.
